summary: This is a Palm Beach Police Department incident report continuation from case 1-05-000368, dated July 13, 2006. It details interviews conducted on November 21, 2005, with two former employees of Jeffrey Epstein, and subsequent communications with Epstein's attorney, Michael Fronstin. The employees describe the frequent presence of young masseuses at Epstein's home and suspicious post-massage cleanup.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the police investigation. Former employees describe his routine of receiving multiple massages per day from young girls at his Palm Beach residence.

persons.name: Michael Fronstin
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who communicates with the police investigator. He relays messages from Epstein, states Epstein will not give a statement, and claims Epstein's massages are therapeutic.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: An attorney whose law office employed a private investigator who contacted a witness. Epstein's attorney, Fronstin, states the investigators were under Black's direction.

persons.name: Donnie Murrell
persons.context: Attorney present during the police interview with the male former employee, identified as the employee's attorney.

persons.name: Ms. Maxwell
persons.context: Identified by a former employee as Epstein's girlfriend. The employee stated he originally dealt with her before dealing directly with Epstein.

persons.name: ASA
persons.context: A prosecutor from the State Attorney's Office who was present to take a statement from a witness during the November 21, 2005, meeting.

connections.description: Fronstin acts as Epstein's legal representative, communicating with police on his behalf and relaying his messages.
Described by a former employee as Epstein's girlfriend, with whom the employee initially interacted regarding household matters.
Fronstin informs the police that private investigators who contacted a witness were under the direction of Attorney Roy Black.
Implied connection as Fronstin states investigators working for Epstein were under Black's direction, suggesting Black was part of Epstein's legal team.

events.title: Police interviews with former Epstein employees
events.description: A Palm Beach police investigator meets with two former Epstein employees at the State Attorney's Office to take their statements. They are interviewed in the presence of their attorneys.

events.title: Witness contacted by private investigator
events.description: A former male employee is contacted by a private investigator from the Law Office of Roy Black, who meets with him at a restaurant to ascertain what he told police.

events.title: Attorney Fronstin relays Epstein's message
events.description: Attorney Michael Fronstin calls the police investigator to relay a message from Jeffrey Epstein. He states Epstein is passionate about therapeutic massages, will not give a statement, and thanks police for keeping the investigation out of the media.

keyFacts: A former male employee of Epstein stated that towards the end of his employment, the masseuses visiting the house appeared to be 'sixteen or seventeen years of age at most.'
The same employee reported that after massages, he would sometimes have to clean a 'massager/vibrator and a long rubber penis' left in the sink, and the bed often needed to be remade.

Epstein's attorney, Michael Fronstin, claimed Epstein was 'very passionate about massages' and had allegedly donated over $100,000 to the Ballet of Florida for massages, which he described as therapeutic.

Private investigators working for Epstein's legal team, under the direction of Attorney Roy Black, contacted a witness after he had spoken to police, which the police investigator viewed as problematic.
The document contains significant redactions, including the names of the two former employees who were interviewed, referred to only as 'She' and 'He'/'Mr. [Redacted].'
